lines.text: Get out before I kill you!
You mean you haven't been tryin'?
it always sticks to one thing 'til it gets there, y'know? I'm sorta like that too.
[Having sworn in his new deputy]
Here's your badge. Don't let anybody see it.
Well, you will fool 'em, Wash. We'll fool 'em together.
The only way to do that is fill 'em full of lead.

No, no, no, what for? You shoot it out with 'em and for some reason or other, I don't know why, they get to look like heroes. But you put 'em behind bars and they look little and cheap, the way they oughta look.
He reminds me of a little kid I used to know. He done in both his pa and ma with a crowbar.
No!
Yes, he did. Now the judge said to him, "Do you got anything to say for yourself?". And the kid said, "Well I just hope that Your Honor has some regard for the feelings of a poor orphan."
Don't let me interfere with your dinner, ma'am.
It's breakfast.
Why, the game was as crooked as a pig's tail!
Please don't mind my brother, Mr. Destry. He's always threatening to blow people's heads off.
I had - I had a friend once. His name was Stubbs. He was always going around threatening to blow people's heads off. One day a fella came along and took him up on it.
Well?
Well, folks say that now Stubbs' forehead is holding up the prettiest tombstone in Greenlawn Cemetery.
All I want is to be a cowboy and to wear my own pants!
I'll bet you've got kind of a lovely face under all that paint, huh? Why don't you wipe it off someday and have a good look - and figure out how you can live up to it.

Oh, Tom! Look here! Look at this post! Soaked through and through with the blood of Sawtooth McGhee. Yeah, he objected to a petticoat a neighbor's wife was wearing... and they fit to a draw. Both are buried in the same grave.
Sawtooth and the petticoat?
No! Sawtooth and the neighbor! And four innocent bystanders!
[Destry & Dimsdale have stopped the gunfight at the Claggett farm. One of Kent's men points a gun at Dimsdale. Destry hits him on the neck with his gloves]
Big bee - about that big - right on the back of your neck. I got him, though.
Thanks.
I ain't one of your weak-livered citizens that busts out cryin' every time you snap your fingers and I ain't gonna pay Kent's fancy prices. Now whaddaya aim to do about it?
Nothin' at present.
That's what I thought. Well, I'll get somethin' done about it if I have to take the law in my own hands!

I used to have a friend that was an opera singer. Then he went into the cement business - and one day he fell into the cement. And now he's the cornerstone of the post office in St. Louis, Missouri. He shoulda stuck to his own trade. You better stick to yours.
Frenchy, am I really Sheriff?
Sure you are!
Then I'm off the liquor. A man's got to choose between the bottle and the badge.
[Wash announces he will send for Tom Destry to be his Deputy Sheriff]
But Destry's dead!
That makes him the right man for the job.
Save us a lot of trouble.

Is that so? Well, young Tom ain't dead and his father brought him up to be the toughest and fightin'est man that ever growed up in the West! He ain't got as big a name as his pa, but he cleaned up Tombstone and I'm sendin' for him to be my deputy and when he gets here, Destry will ride again!
[Boris has bet and lost his pants in game of poker]
Frenchy, think of my position. I've met every king in Europe!
Now you've met two aces in Bottleneck. Off with your pants.
I collect Deputy Sheriff's guns. Whenever I meet a new deputy, I ask him for his gun and I ask him real nice.
I'm sorry, Mr. Kent. I'm afraid this here's one gun your collection's going to be minus.
You mean I'm going to have to take it?

If you can. Now, hold on! Hold on. Don't get excited here. I'm just tryin' to tell you that I ain't got any guns. You see if I woulda had a gun then, why, one of us might have been hurt and it might be me. I wouldn't want that to happen... would I?
Hey you! Give me those pants. And from now now on, leave my husband alone.
I don't want your husband, Mrs. Callahan - all I want is his money... and his pants.
And how'd you get 'em? By making eyes at him while you cheated, you gilded lily!
But Mrs. Callahan, you know he would rather be cheated by me than married to you.
How are you going to face anybody after what you took from Kent and Frenchy?
Whadja expect me to do?
I expected you to be like your pa, comin' out blasting behind your shootin' irons! And what happened? You didn't have any? Why?
I don't believe in 'em.
You did the last time I heard about ya. What in thunder has come over ya since then?
Wash, my pa had these
[guns]
on that day in Tombstone when he got shot in the back. Didn't seem to do him much good, did they? That's one reason I don't believe in 'em.
What in tarnation do you believe in?
Law and order.
Without guns?
Without 'em!
Observe my brain in action. Now where would I go if I were a dead body? Would I stay in the open? No - no privacy.
Mm-hmm. Wouldn't go in the river if you can't swim.
Why didn't I stay in the gutter where I was well off?
Would I go under the ground? No - there's no future in it.
[last lines]
I'm sorry, Tom, but it sounded like murder at least.
Oh, well. That's probably just the Russian way of expressin' somethin'. You know, speakin' of marriage, Janice...
Yes, Tom?
I had a friend once...

According to the provisions of the statutes of our territorial commonwealth, you gentleman of the jury have been selected as representative citizens of our fair community. We want to see that the public's faith is justified. So when you boys retire to consider a verdict, stay out awhile. Mr. Kent will see that you are plentifuly provided with liquid refreshments. And after you have deliberated sufficiently, weighed all the evidence fair and square, and brought in a verdict of not guilty, you will be amply rewarded. You understand?
